draft-brockners-inband-oam-requirements-00 draft-brockners-inband-oam-requirements-01
Abstract Abstract
This document discusses the motivation and requirements for including This document discusses the motivation and requirements for including
specific operational and telemetry information into data packets specific operational and telemetry information into data packets
while the data packet traverses a path between two points in the while the data packet traverses a path between two points in the
network. This method is referred to as "in-band" Operations, network. This method is referred to as "in-band" Operations,
Administration, and Maintenance (OAM), given that the OAM information Administration, and Maintenance (OAM), given that the OAM information
is carried with the data packets as opposed to in "out-of-band" is carried with the data packets as opposed to in "out-of-band"
packets dedicated to OAM. In-band OAM complements other OAM packets dedicated to OAM. In-band OAM complements other OAM

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
This document discusses requirements for "in-band" Operations, This document discusses requirements for "in-band" Operations,
Administration, and Maintenance (OAM) mechanisms. "In-band" OAM Administration, and Maintenance (OAM) mechanisms. "In-band" OAM
means to record OAM and telemetry information within the data packet means to record OAM and telemetry information within the data packet
while the data packet traverses a network or a particular network while the data packet traverses a network or a particular network
domain. The term "in-band" refers to the fact that the OAM and domain. The term "in-band" refers to the fact that the OAM and
telemetry data is carried within data packets rather than being sent telemetry data is carried within data packets rather than being sent
within packets specifically dedicated to OAM. In-band OAM within packets specifically dedicated to OAM. In-band OAM
skipping to change at page 8, line 15 skipping to change at page 8, line 22
between the different trust domains, because the hand-off-points are between the different trust domains, because the hand-off-points are
no longer clearly defined physical interfaces, but are virtual no longer clearly defined physical interfaces, but are virtual
interfaces. Because of that very reason, networks operators require interfaces. Because of that very reason, networks operators require
that different trust layers not to be mixed in the same device. For that different trust layers not to be mixed in the same device. For
an NFV scenario a different proof is required. Offering a proof that an NFV scenario a different proof is required. Offering a proof that
a packet traversed a specific set of service functions would allow a packet traversed a specific set of service functions would allow
network operators to move away from the above described indirect network operators to move away from the above described indirect
methods of proving that a service chain is in place for a particular methods of proving that a service chain is in place for a particular
application. application.
Deployed service chains without the presence of a "proof of transit"
mechanism are typically operated as fail-open system: The packets
that arrive at the end of a service chain are processed. Adding
"proof of transit" capabilites to a service chain allows an operator
to turn a fail-open system into a fail-close system, i.e. packets
that did not properly traverse the service chain can be blocked.
A solution approach could be based on OAM data which is added to A solution approach could be based on OAM data which is added to
every packet for achieving Proof Of Transit. The OAM data is updated every packet for achieving Proof Of Transit. The OAM data is updated
at every hop and is used to verify whether a packet traversed all at every hop and is used to verify whether a packet traversed all
required nodes. When the verifier receives each packet, it can required nodes. When the verifier receives each packet, it can
validate whether the packet traversed the service chain correctly. validate whether the packet traversed the service chain correctly.
The detailed mechanisms used for path verification along with the The detailed mechanisms used for path verification along with the
procedures applied to the OAM data carried in the packet for path procedures applied to the OAM data carried in the packet for path
verification are beyond the scope of this document. Details are verification are beyond the scope of this document. Details are
addressed in [draft-brockners-proof-of-transit]. In this document addressed in [draft-brockners-proof-of-transit]. In this document
the term "proof" refers to a discrete set of bits that represents an the term "proof" refers to a discrete set of bits that represents an

4. Considerations for In-band OAM 4. Considerations for In-band OAM
The implementation of an in-band OAM mechanism needs to take several The implementation of an in-band OAM mechanism needs to take several
considerations into account, including administrative boundaries, how considerations into account, including administrative boundaries, how
information is recorded, Maximum Transfer Unit (MTU), Path MTU information is recorded, Maximum Transfer Unit (MTU), Path MTU
discovery and packet size, etc. discovery and packet size, etc.
4.1. Type of Information to Be Recorded 4.1. Type of information to be recorded
The information gathered for in-band OAM can be categorized into The information gathered for in-band OAM can be categorized into
three main categories: Information with a per-hop scope, such as path three main categories: Information with a per-hop scope, such as path
tracing; information which applies to a specific set of nodes, such tracing; information which applies to a specific set of nodes, such
as path or service chain verification; information which only applies as path or service chain verification; information which only applies
to the edges of a domain, such as sequence numbers. to the edges of a domain, such as sequence numbers.
o "edge to edge": Information that needs to be shared between o "edge to edge": Information that needs to be shared between
network edges (the "edge" of a network could either be a host or a network edges (the "edge" of a network could either be a host or a
domain edge device): Edge to edge data e.g., packet and octet domain edge device): Edge to edge data e.g., packet and octet
skipping to change at page 10, line 22 skipping to change at page 10, line 38
* Hop by Hop information e.g., Nodes visited for path tracing, * Hop by Hop information e.g., Nodes visited for path tracing,
Timestamps at each hop to find delays along the path Timestamps at each hop to find delays along the path
* Stats collection at each hop to optimize communication in * Stats collection at each hop to optimize communication in
resource constrained networks e.g., Battery, CPU, memory status resource constrained networks e.g., Battery, CPU, memory status
of each node piggy backed in a data packet is useful in low of each node piggy backed in a data packet is useful in low
power lossy networks where network nodes are mostly asleep and power lossy networks where network nodes are mostly asleep and
communication is expensive communication is expensive
4.2. MTU and Packet Size 4.2. MTU and packet size
The recorded data at every hop may lead to packet size exceeding the The recorded data at every hop may lead to packet size exceeding the
Maximum Transmit Unit (MTU). Based on the transport protocol used Maximum Transmit Unit (MTU). Based on the transport protocol used
MTU is discovered as a configuration parameter or Path MTU (PMTU) is MTU is discovered as a configuration parameter or Path MTU (PMTU) is
discovered dynamically. Example: IPv6 recommends PMTU discovery discovered dynamically. Example: IPv6 recommends PMTU discovery
before data packets are sent to prevent packet fragmentation. It before data packets are sent to prevent packet fragmentation. It
specifies 1280 octets as the default PDU to be carried in a IPv6 specifies 1280 octets as the default PDU to be carried in a IPv6
datagram. A detailed discussion of the implications of oversized datagram. A detailed discussion of the implications of oversized
IPv6 header chains if found in [RFC7112]. IPv6 header chains if found in [RFC7112].

discovered dynamically. Example: IPv6 recommends PMTU discovery discovered dynamically. Example: IPv6 recommends PMTU discovery
before data packets are sent to prevent packet fragmentation. It before data packets are sent to prevent packet fragmentation. It

The Path MTU restricts the amount of data that can be recorded for The Path MTU restricts the amount of data that can be recorded for
purpose of OAM within a data packet. The total size of data to be purpose of OAM within a data packet. The total size of data to be
recorded needs to be preset to avoid packet size exceeding the MTU. recorded needs to be preset to avoid packet size exceeding the MTU.
It is recommended to pre-calculate and configures network devices to It is recommended to pre-calculate and configures network devices to
limit the in-band OAM data that is attached to a packet. limit the in-band OAM data that is attached to a packet.
4.3. Administrative Boundaries 4.3. Administrative boundaries
There are challenges in enabling in-band OAM in the public Internet There are several challenges in enabling in-band OAM in the public
across administrative domains: Internet as well as in corporate/enterprise networks across
administrative domains, which include but are not limited to:
o Deployment dependent, the data fields that in-band OAM requires as o Deployment dependent, the data fields that in-band OAM requires as
part of a specific transport protocol may not be supported across part of a specific transport protocol may not be supported across
administrative boundaries. administrative boundaries.
o Current OAM implementations are often done in the slow path, i.e., o Current OAM implementations are often done in the slow path, i.e.,
OAM packets are punted to router's CPU for processing. This leads OAM packets are punted to router's CPU for processing. This leads
to performance and scaling issues and opens up routers for attacks to performance and scaling issues and opens up routers for attacks
such as Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. such as Denial of Service (DoS) attacks.
o Discovery of network topology and details of the network devices o Discovery of network topology and details of the network devices
across administrative boundaries may open up attack vectors across administrative boundaries may open up attack vectors
compromising network security. compromising network security.
o Specifically on IPv6: At the administrative boundaries IPv6 o Specifically on IPv6: At the administrative boundaries IPv6
packets with extension headers are dropped for several reasons packets with extension headers are dropped for several reasons
described in [RFC7872] described in [RFC7872].
The following considerations will be discussed in a future version of The following considerations will be discussed in a future version of
this document: If the packet is dropped due to the presence of the this document: If the packet is dropped due to the presence of the
in-band OAM; If the policy failure is treated as feature disablement in-band OAM; If the policy failure is treated as feature disablement
and any further recording is stopped but the packet itself is not and any further recording is stopped but the packet itself is not
dropped, it may lead to every node in the path to make this policy dropped, it may lead to every node in the path to make this policy
decision. decision.
4.4. Selective Enablement 4.4. Selective enablement
Deployment dependent, in-band OAM could either be used for all, or Deployment dependent, in-band OAM could either be used for all, or
only a subset of the overall traffic. While it might be desirable to only a subset of the overall traffic. While it might be desirable to
apply in-band OAM to all traffic and then selectively use the data apply in-band OAM to all traffic and then selectively use the data
gathered in case needed, it might not always be feasible. Depending gathered in case needed, it might not always be feasible. Depending
on the forwarding infrastructure used, in-band OAM can have an impact on the forwarding infrastructure used, in-band OAM can have an impact
on forwarding performance. The SPUD prototype for example uses the on forwarding performance. The SPUD prototype for example uses the
notion of "pipes" to describe the portion of the traffic that could notion of "pipes" to describe the portion of the traffic that could
be subject to in-path inspection. Mechanisms to decide which traffic be subject to in-path inspection. Mechanisms to decide which traffic
would be subject to in-band OAM are outside the scope of this would be subject to in-band OAM are outside the scope of this
document. document.
4.5. Optimization of Node and Interface Identifiers 4.5. Optimization of node and interface identifiers
Since packets have a finite maximum size, the data recording or Since packets have a finite maximum size, the data recording or
carrying capacity of one packet in which the in-band OAM meta data is carrying capacity of one packet in which the in-band OAM meta data is
present is limited. In-band OAM should use its own dedicated present is limited. In-band OAM should use its own dedicated
namespace (confined to the domain in-band OAM operates in) to namespace (confined to the domain in-band OAM operates in) to
represent node and interface IDs to save space in the header. represent node and interface IDs to save space in the header.
Generic representations of node and interface identifiers which are Generic representations of node and interface identifiers which are
globally unique (such as a UUID) would consume significantly more globally unique (such as a UUID) would consume significantly more
bits of in-band OAM data. bits of in-band OAM data.

issues a packet and inserts in-band OAM data, the recorded data needs issues a packet and inserts in-band OAM data, the recorded data needs
to be carried back to the source node. to be carried back to the source node.

appropriately on the ping/ping6 mechanism, the following two appropriately on the ping/ping6 mechanism, the following two
operations should be implemented by the ping/ping6 target node: operations should be implemented by the ping/ping6 target node:
